sen.j: 高天原（たかあまはら、たかのあまはら、たかまのはら、たかまがはら）は『古事記』の日本神話と祝詞に於ける天津神の住まう場所である。
sen.e: Takamanohara (also called Takaamahara/ Takanoamahara/ Takamagahara) is a place where Amatsu kami (god of heaven) lives in the Japanese mythology and norito (Shinto prayer) in "Kojiki" (The Records of Ancient Matters).

Takamanohara (also called Takaamahara/ Takanoamahara/ Takamagahara) is a place where Amatsu kami (god of heaven) lives in the Japanese mythology and norito (Shinto prayer) in "Kojiki" (The Records of Ancient Matters).

Takamanohara (also called Takaamahara/ Takanoamahara/ Takamagahara) is a place where Amatsu kami (god of heaven) lives in the Japanese mythology and norito (Shinto prayer) in "Kojiki" (The Records of Ancient Matters).

sen.j: 地上の人間が住む世界である葦原中国や、地中にあるとされる根の国・黄泉に対し、天上界にあったとされる。
sen.e: In contrast to Ashihara no nakatsukuni (Literally, "Central Land of Reed Plains", which refers to the human world) where people lived, and Nenokuni (Land of the Roots) and Yomi (realm of the dead) where is said to have been underground, it is said to have been located in the heavenly realms.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: In contrast to Ashihara no nakatsukuni (Literally, "Central Land of Reed Plains", which refers to the human world) where people lived, and Nenokuni (Land of the Roots) and Yomi (realm of the dead) where is said to have been underground, it is said to have been located in the heavenly realms.

In contrast to Ashihara no nakatsukuni (Literally, "Central Land of Reed Plains", which refers to the human world) where people lived, and Nenokuni (Land of the Roots) and Yomi (realm of the dead) where is said to have been underground, it is said to have been located in the heavenly realms.

sen.j: 古くから神話を現実的に解釈しようという要求から、大和、九州、北陸、富士山等実在の場所であったとの説もとなえられた。
sen.e: Since ancient times, there have been a view that it was located in the real place such as Yamato, Kyushu region, Hokuriku region, or Mt. Fuji from a viewpoint of interpreting the mythology realistically.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Since ancient times, there has been a view that it was located in the real place such as Yamato, Kyushu region, Hokuriku region, or Mt. Fuji from a viewpoint of interpreting the mythology realistically.

sen.j: 原文は漢文であるため、どの訓が正しいかは或る程度推測にとどまる。
sen.e: Because the original text was written in kanbun (Sino-Japanese), it is to some extent a supposition that which readings of Chinese characters are correct.

sen.j: ただし、古事記冒頭には「訓高下天云阿麻下效此」とあり、天はアマと読むように指定がある。
sen.e: However, in the opening line of Kojiki tells that '訓高下天云阿麻下效此,' which designates us to read the Chinese character '天' as 'ama.'
sen.cmt: 「訓高下天云阿麻下效此」の箇所が「天はアマと読むように」という意味ではないかと思われますので、「訓高下天云阿麻下效此」は漢文のままとしました。
sen.e: However, in the opening line of Kojiki tells that '訓高下天云阿麻下效此,' which designates us to read the Chinese character '天' as 'ama.'

sen.j: 通常は、「たかまがはら」という格助詞【が】を用いた読み方が一般的であるが、この読み方が広まったのは歴史的には新しいとされている。
sen.e: Normally, the way of reading 'Takamagahara,' which uses case particle 'ga,' is common, but it is said that this way of reading spread quite recently in the history.

sen.j: 古事記においては、その冒頭に「天地（あめつち）のはじめ」に神々の生まれ出る場所としてその名が登場する。
sen.e: In Kojiki, the name is mentioned as a place from which gods were born in 'ametsuchi no hajime' (the beginning of heaven and earth).
At the beginning of Kojiki, the name is mentioned as a place from which gods were born in 'ametsuchi no hajime' (the beginning of heaven and earth).
sen.cmt: 訳漏れの補足をしました。
sen.e: At the beginning of Kojiki, the name is mentioned as a place from which gods were born in 'ametsuchi no hajime' (the beginning of heaven and earth).

sen.j: 次々に神々が生まれ、国生みの二柱の神が矛を下ろして島を作るくだりがあるから、海の上の雲の中に存在したことが想定されていたのであろう。
sen.e: Then gods were born one after another, and because of the passage in which two gods of kuni-umi (the birth of (the land) of Japan) put down a pike and made islands, it seems to have been considered to exist in the clouds above the sea.

Then gods were born one after another, and because of the passage in which two gods of kuni-umi (the birth of [the land] of Japan) put down a pike and made islands, it seems to have been considered to exist in the clouds above the sea.

sen.j: 天照大神が生まれたときに、高天原を治めるよう命じられた。
sen.e: When Amaterasu Omikami (The Sun Goddess) was born, she was ordered to rule Takamanohara.
When Amaterasu Omikami (The Sun Goddess) was born, she was ordered to rule Takamanohara.
When Amaterasu Omikami (The Sun Goddess) was born, she was ordered to rule Takamanohara.

sen.j: 須佐男命にまつわる部分では、高天原には多くの神々（天津神）が住み、機織の場などもあったことが記述されており、人間世界に近い生活があったとの印象がある。
sen.e: In the part concerning Susanoo no Mikoto (a god in the Japanese mythology), there is a description which says that many gods (Amatsu kami) lived in Takamanohara and there was a place to weave at, which gives us an impression that they led a life similar to the people.

In the part concerning Susanoo no Mikoto (a god in the Japanese mythology), there is a description which says that many gods (Amatsu kami) lived in Takamanohara and there was a place to weave at, which gives us an impression that they led a life similar to the people.

In the part concerning Susanoo no Mikoto (a god in the Japanese mythology), there is a description which says that many gods (Amatsu kami) lived in Takamanohara and there was a place to weave at, which gives us an impression that they led a life similar to the people.

sen.j: 葦原中国が天津神によって平定され、天照大神の孫のニニギが天降り（天孫降臨）、以降、天孫の子孫である天皇が葦原中国を治めることになったとしている。
sen.e: Amatsu kami suppressed Ashihara no nakatsukuni, so Ninigi, a grandchild of Amaterasu Omikami, went down from the heaven (tenson korin (descent of the heavenly grandchild)), and since then Emperors who were descendants of the grandson of the sun goddess had ruled Ashihara no nakatsukuni.

Amatsu kami suppressed Ashihara no nakatsukuni, so Ninigi, a grandchild of Amaterasu Omikami, went down from the heaven (tenson korin [descent of the heavenly grandchild]), and since then Emperors who were descendants of the grandson of the sun goddess had ruled Ashihara no nakatsukuni.

Amatsu kami suppressed Ashihara no nakatsukuni, so Ninigi, a grandchild of Amaterasu Omikami, went down from the heaven (tenson korin [descent of the heavenly grandchild]), and since then Emperors who were descendants of the grandson of the sun goddess had ruled Ashihara no nakatsukuni.

sen.j: 『日本書紀』においては本文にはほとんどみえず、わずかに第4の一書と養老4年（720年）に代々の天皇とともに持統天皇につけられた和風諡号「高天原廣野姫天皇」がある。
sen.e: "Nihonshoki" (Chronicles of Japan) hardly has a text which mentions Takamanohara, and it can be seen only in the fourth alternate writing and the wafu-shigo (Japanese-style posthumous name) of 'Takamanohara hironohime no sumeramikoto,' which was given to Emperor Jito along with the successive emperors in 720.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: "Nihonshoki" (Chronicles of Japan) hardly has a text which mentions Takamanohara, and it can be seen only in the fourth alternate writing and the wafu-shigo (Japanese-style posthumous name) of 'Takamanohara hironohime no sumeramikoto,' which was given to Emperor Jito along with the successive emperors in 720.

sen.j: また、『古語拾遺』本文では1箇所天孫降臨の神勅と、他に祝詞説明の注に、現存の風土記では『常陸風土記』冒頭2語あるのみである。
sen.e: "Kogo shui" (Gleanings of Old Words) mentions the name only in an oracle of tenson korin and note on norito, and among the extant fudoki (description of regional climate, culture, etc.), "Hitachi Fudoki" mentions the name only twice in the opening line.

sen.j: 高天原の所在地については古来より諸説あり、古事記における神話をどうとらえるかによりその立場が大きく異なる。
sen.e: There has been various theories on the location of Takamanohara since ancient times, and the viewpoints are quite different due to the way of interpreting the myths in Kojiki.

sen.j: 神話は作られたものであるから、そこに出てくる高天原がどこにあったかなどと考えること自体が無意味であるとする説。
sen.e: It is an opinion that in the first place myths are something that were artificially created, so it is nonsense to think where Takamanohara was located.

sen.j: 山片蟠桃の説が代表的なもので、古事記における神代のことは後世の作為であるとする。
sen.e: This is represented by Banto YAMAGATA's opinion, and he claimed that the age of the gods in Kojiki was artificially made by posterity.

sen.j: 戦後主流となっている津田左右吉の史観はこの考え方に基づく。
sen.e: A historical view of Sokichi TSUDA, which has been the main current after WWII, was based on this idea.

sen.j: 現在でもほとんどの学者は、高天原神話は支配階級を天上界に由来するが故に尊いとする信仰を語ったものであるという説に与している。
sen.e: Today, most of the scholars agree with the opinion that a myth of Takamanohara is important because those who belonged to the governing class were derived from the heavenly world.

sen.e: In today's history, such a theory is generally avoided because it is considered just a pick-and-choose attitude and not persuasive.

sen.j: ここに所在する高天彦神社は、延喜式では最高の社格とされた名神［みょうじん］大社で、祭神は葛城氏の祖神高皇産霊［たかみむすび］神。
sen.e: Takamahiko-jinja Shrine located here is a Myojin taisha (grand shrine), which was considered the highest shrine ranking in Engi shiki (one of the earliest extant written records of imperial court etiquette compiled in the Engi era), and the enshrined deity is Takamimusubi, the founder of the Katsuragi clan.

sen.j: 高千穂神社では、アメノウズメが舞ったことから始まったとされる高千穂の夜神楽が伝承されている。
sen.e: Takachiho no Yokagura (ancient Shinto music and dancing which starts in the night and ends in the morning), which is said to have begun by the dance performed by Amenouzume (goddess of entertainment), has been handed down in Takachijo-jinja Shrine.

sen.j: 高天原神話の発祥の神宮である「日の宮･弊立神宮」がある。
sen.e: The district has 'Hi no miya/ Heitate-jingu Shrine,' which is the birthplace of the Takamanohara myth.

sen.j: 御神体は豊国文字と阿比留文字が彫られた石板であり、「アソヒノオオカミ」と「日文」が表裏に刻まれている。
sen.e: The object of worship enshrined here is a slate on which Toyokuni letters and Abirumoji letters were engraved, and the back and front of it has letters 'Asohino Okami' and '日文' (literally, the sun letters).
sen.cmt: 「日文」の意味がわかりませんでした。

sen.cmt: 石の訳漏れを入れました。

sen.j: なみに「弊立」とはヒモロギを意味し、太古 天の神が御降臨になった聖なる地とされている。
sen.e: Heitate' means himorogi (an abode of the gods), and it is considered the sacred land where the heavenly god descended in ancient times.

sen.j: 小さな穴として従来から知られていたが、昭和4年に奥へと長く続いていることが発見された。

sen.j: 狼の骨が多数発見されたことから命名、内部に高天原や天の安河原などと名づけられた場所がある。
sen.e: The name was derived from a discovery of many bones of wolves, and in the cave, there are places which were named Takamanohara, Ama no Yasukawa, and so on.
